urls.title: Invasive Species Week - GB non-native species secretariat
urls.description: It's Invasive Species Week! Throughout the week lots of events and activities will be taking place that people can take part in online or socially distanced. We know that many have been finding solace in nature over the last year, and we will be sharing some simple tips to help you protect the environment. Follow along at @InvasiveSp (external link) or #INNSweek to be added to the mailing list for updates. Take a look at all the activities and materials that have been released this week, and see a list of

tweets.text:
It’s national invasive species week highlighting the threat to ecology & wildlife of our rivers and lakes. This is a top mouth gudgeon which can eat eggs & larvae of native #fish. 
Make sure you check, clean & dry equipment after use to stop spread #INNS 
https://t.co/EglaQ6mNf6 https://t.co/0RbLTQxdKy
@wouldforthetree @EnvAgency Ah, yes, the joy that is 'brasiliensis' - I am trying to tackle that one.

tweets.text: Great to visit the #DerwentReservoir (down the middle is the boundary between #NorthWestDurham and #Hexham constituencies) to learn more a out our water supply, the impact of Covid and the environmental issues @nwater_care are dealing with https://t.co/lj61n7oNY7

It’s #InvasiveSpecies week!
Invasive non-native species reduce the ability of native wildlife to cope with other pressures such as climate change & habitat loss. 
This week we’ll be sharing content about invasive non-native species &what you can do to help 
#INNSweek @InvasiveSp https://t.co/UPv86RxO35

#StopTheStink: @PHE_uk and @EnvAgencyMids, since this is now a medium-term issue (90-days), why is the more stringent WHO tolerability of 20 μg m¯³ hydrogen sulphide not applied when considering respiratory effects? (Ref: Page 5 of https://t.co/0IJ1VGs9pk) https://t.co/tkqsRQ1FxM

urls.title: Why society needs nature - Lessons from research during Covid-19 - Forest Research

tweets.text: New report outlines the benefits of nature for physical / mental wellbeing during Covid-19 and lessons learnt https://t.co/AmBDHYrTI9  From a collaboration between @EnvAgency @Forest_Research @nature_scot @NaturalEngland @NatResWales #PeopleWithNature #ConnectingPeopleWithNature https://t.co/2oZZ5p29Tg
@fungi_flowers @EnvAgency Jesus. Maybe they'll announce it's okay because they bought it from their local garden centre as Myrophyllum 'brasiliensis'?

Well done to double winner @The_Skill_Mill for achieving the Sustainable Development & Promoting Opportunity Award. “To be awarded one Queen’s Award is amazing, to get two is something none of us could ever have imagined." Davie Parks, Founder & Managing Director #QueensAwards https://t.co/ysJXNrif0L

urls.title: UK Junior Water Prize - CIWEM
urls.description: An annual competition organised by CIWEM, in partnership with the Stockholm International Water Institute, inspiring students to solve our biggest global environmental challenges associated with water.

tweets.text:
Aged between 15 and 20 for #WorldWaterWeek 2021 and have an idea for solving an environmental challenge linked to water? 
Why not enter the UK Junior Water Prize? 
Entries close May 28th.
Full details here: https://t.co/v1BGkSsa60
@EnvAgency @siwi_water @JacobsConnects #STEM https://t.co/tzoxSuCHTx

#TogetherForOurPlanet #NetZero https://t.co/pE7ql2Paxe

entity.name: Great British Railway Journeys
entity.description: Cartographer George Bradshaw produced the first comprehensive timetable and travel guide of Great Britain's railway system in 1840. Armed with his Bradshaw's Guide, presenter Michael Portillo travels around the country by train exploring the ways that society and industry have changed since the guide was first published during the Victorian era. In each destination Michael visits local landmarks, meets residents, enjoys local food, and tries his hand at local crafts and manufacture, and considers the legacy of the industrial revolution as he makes he way across the country.

urls.title: Testing and sequencing of sewage ramped up to help tackle COVID-19 outbreaks
urls.description: The innovative programme to test wastewater for traces of coronavirus (COVID-19) has ramped up sequencing capacity to support variant detection.

tweets.text:
Testing and sequencing of sewage for #COVID19 is being increased to:

▶️ understand where the virus is circulating
▶️ detect variants
▶️ help tackle outbreaks

Dr Jonathan Porter from @EnvAgency explains how this process works 👇 

More info ▶️ https://t.co/7OOtM4oIHT https://t.co/x3vvNUbr5V
